creator: pointman@geekteck.com
text:
If ErrorDocument ### /correct_file does not report the document file as 
missing when looking at the error_log, AllowOverride is set properly for the 
directory, and the .htaccess file has the correct permissions, Internet 
Explorer may not display the correct ErrorDocument if 
  Tools-Internet Options-Advanced-Show friendly HTTP error messages
is enabled.  Turning this off displays the correct error document.

Another option is to change the entry and let the browser resolve the document 
location.  This, however, won't report the error to the browser (or spider).

Example: ErrorDocument 404 /errors/not_found.html
Becomes: ErrorDocument 404 http://www.mysite.com/errors/not_found.html

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
The first sentence of your report borders on indecipherable, but if you are
reporting that MSIE sometimes ignores server-generated error messages, I don't
see why that is a bug in Apache.

You can work-around this MSIE problem by making your error documents
"sufficiently large".

Thanks for using Apache!

creator: pointman@geekteck.com
text:
For clarity, I should have stated Internet Explorer not showing an 
ErrorDocument because of "Show friendly HTTP error messages" is not an Apache 
bug.  The IE setting isn't in Apache documentation as being the source of the 
problem, and much time can be wasted searching Apache configuration files for 
non-obvious settings like AllowOverride in httpd.conf (which is documented).

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
Well, okay.

It's documented in 2.0, and that is where we put most of our documentation
effort, but I'll reopen this and properly assign it in case someone feels
like fixing it in 1.3.
